p:
Despite the potential for COVID-19 to induce ACS, the number of reported cases of ACS during the COVID-19 outbreak in Italy, Spain and the USA was actually significantly lower than during pre-COVID-19 periods, with a reported 42–48% reduction in hospitalizations for ACS and a 38–40% reduction in percutaneous coronary interventions for ST segment elevation myocardial infarction
70– 73 . By contrast, the incidence of out-of-hospital cardiac arrest increased during the COVID-19 outbreak in Italy, which was strongly associated with the cumulative incidence of COVID-19 (ref.
74 ). This observation is in accordance with the finding that the number of patients with myocardial infarction seeking urgent hospital care declined by >50% during the peak of the COVID-19 outbreak, as reported in an extensive global survey by the ESC
75 .
